<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Molecular structure unit with atom labeling of the title compound and ellipsoids are at 30% probability. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Molecular structure unit with atom labeling of the title compound and ellipsoids are at 30% probability. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  View of the one-dimensional chain in the title compound. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) Coordination environment of Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> in the title compound. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) Coordination polyhedron around Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> in the title compound.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  (a) Coordination environment of Gd3+ in the title compound. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) Coordination polyhedron around Gd3+ in the title compound.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel compound, [{Gd(NMP)6}(PMo12O40)] n , has been synthesized and characterized by IR, and UV spectroscopy, and single crystal X-ray structural analysis. It forms an unprecedented one-dimensional zigzag chain built from alternating polyanions and cationic units through Mo-O t -Gd-O t -Mo links in the crystal. In the compound, Gd3+ is eight-coordinated with a bicapped trigonal prism geometry environment of oxygen atoms. The results of the single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and IR are agreement and both show the metal cation units are coordinately bonded to the Keggin cluster. The UV spectrum of the title compound suggests that the compound is entirely dissociated in dilute solution.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">As a rich and diverse class of inorganic cluster systems, the polyoxometalate ions formed by the early transition metals are characterized by fascinating structural, electrochemical, catalytic, magnetic, medicinal, and photophysical properties . In the fields of designing and assembling molecule-based materials  with structures constructed by so-called anion–cation salts or host–guest solids, polyoxometalates have been found to be extremely versatile inorganic building blocks due to their ability to accept electrons . So far, many intermolecular complexes based on polyoxometalates have been synthesized and reported . Through electron transfer between organic units and polyanions, some can enhance SHG nonlinear optical response , some enhance electric, or magnetic properties . The interactions existing in organic substrate and heteropoly acids or salts are mainly facilitated by hydrogen bonds, Van der Waals forces, and electrostatic forces in their structure. However, infinitely extended chains based on Keggin or Dawson type anions and joined together by W(Mo)–O<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>t</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–M  links are relatively rare. Structurally characterized notable examples include [ET]<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>[PMnW<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">39</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O,  [NEt<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H]<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>[XCoW<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">39</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (X=P or As),  [Cu(en)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>en][{Cu(en)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CuW<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">61</ce:inf>]·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (en=ethylenediamine), and [Cu(en)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Cu(en)]<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>[H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>en]<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>[{Cu (en)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CuW<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">61</ce:inf>]·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O,  [{Ba(DMSO)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SiMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>)], [{Ba(DMSO)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}{Ba(DMSO)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)GeMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>}],  and [{Ca(DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SiMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As a rich and diverse class of inorganic cluster systems, the polyoxometalate ions formed by the early transition metals are characterized by fascinating structural, electrochemical, catalytic, magnetic, medicinal, and photophysical properties . In the fields of designing and assembling molecule-based materials  with structures constructed by so-called anion-cation salts or host-guest solids, polyoxometalates have been found to be extremely versatile inorganic building blocks due to their ability to accept electrons . So far, many intermolecular complexes based on polyoxometalates have been synthesized and reported . Through electron transfer between organic units and polyanions, some can enhance SHG nonlinear optical response , some enhance electric, or magnetic properties . The interactions existing in organic substrate and heteropoly acids or salts are mainly facilitated by hydrogen bonds, Van der Waals forces, and electrostatic forces in their structure. However, infinitely extended chains based on Keggin or Dawson type anions and joined together by W(Mo)-O t -M  links are relatively rare. Structurally characterized notable examples include [ET]8[PMnW11O39]⋅2H2O,  [NEt3H]5[XCoW11O39]⋅3H2O (X=P or As),  [Cu(en)2(OH2)]2[H2en][{Cu(en)2}P2CuW17O61]⋅5H2O (en=ethylenediamine), and [Cu(en)2(OH2)]2[Cu(en)]0.5[H2en]0.5[{Cu (en)2}P2CuW17O61]⋅5H2O,  [{Ba(DMSO)5(H2O)}2(SiMo12O40)], [{Ba(DMSO)3(H2O)3}{Ba(DMSO)5(H2O)GeMo12O40}],  and [{Ca(DMF)5}2SiMo12O40] n  .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In polyoxometalate chemistry, one of the major challenge is the ‘rational’ synthesis of new compounds. The development of rational methods for the modification and functionalization of polyoxometalate systems may provide the means to exploit more fully these desirable attributes mentioned above. From the standpoint of molecular design, we attempted to use normal synthesis to realize such molecular assemblies. Firstly, we introduced metal ions into the framework formed by polyanions and organic units, so that the combination of polyanions and organic units through metal ions can be realized. Here, we chose lanthanide(III) [Ln(III)] metal ions, which have potential uses in bioinorganic chemistry and materials science . Secondly, We chose NMP molecules as electron donors, since polyoxometalate-anions are good electron acceptors, thus, they can interact, leading to electron transfer. Here, we report the synthesis and X-ray single crystal structure analyses of an infinitely extended polyoxometalate-based composite: [{Gd(NMP)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}(PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>. In its structure the rare-earth ions are firstly coordinated by six NMP and polyanion ligands to form a structure unit, then these structure units are connected through Mo–O<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>t</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–Gd–O<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>t</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–Mo  links to construct one-dimensional (1D) chain-like structures. To our knowledge, the type of structure exhibited by the compound has never been reported previously. This paper focuses primarily on solid-state structural aspects of an organic–inorganic complex with the novel structure, in which infinite stacking assemblies between polyanions and cationic units are achieved. The structure of the title compound may serve as useful models for the design of functional molecular assemblies.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In polyoxometalate chemistry, one of the major challenge is the ‘rational' synthesis of new compounds. The development of rational methods for the modification and functionalization of polyoxometalate systems may provide the means to exploit more fully these desirable attributes mentioned above. From the standpoint of molecular design, we attempted to use normal synthesis to realize such molecular assemblies. Firstly, we introduced metal ions into the framework formed by polyanions and organic units, so that the combination of polyanions and organic units through metal ions can be realized. Here, we chose lanthanide(III) [Ln(III)] metal ions, which have potential uses in bioinorganic chemistry and materials science . Secondly, We chose NMP molecules as electron donors, since polyoxometalate-anions are good electron acceptors, thus, they can interact, leading to electron transfer. Here, we report the synthesis and X-ray single crystal structure analyses of an infinitely extended polyoxometalate-based composite: [{Gd(NMP)6}(PMo12O40)] n . In its structure the rare-earth ions are firstly coordinated by six NMP and polyanion ligands to form a structure unit, then these structure units are connected through Mo-O t -Gd-O t -Mo  links to construct one-dimensional (1D) chain-like structures. To our knowledge, the type of structure exhibited by the compound has never been reported previously. This paper focuses primarily on solid-state structural aspects of an organic-inorganic complex with the novel structure, in which infinite stacking assemblies between polyanions and cationic units are achieved. The structure of the title compound may serve as useful models for the design of functional molecular assemblies.

GdCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was prepared through adding concentrated HCl to Gd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (99.9%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Preparation of the title compound

All organic solvents and materials used for synthesis were of reagent grade and used without further purification. α-H3PMo12O40⋅nH2O were prepared according to the literature method . GdCl3 was prepared through adding concentrated HCl to Gd2O3 (99.9%).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">[{Gd(NMP)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}(PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>. The formation of heteropolyacid gadolinium salts was realized by neutralization of the acids. α-H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>·<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (3.8 g, 2 mmol) and GdCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (2 mmol) were dissolved in 15 ml water, and the solution was heated at a 80 °C water bath until being dry. Then 2 ml NMP was added to dried solid (2 g) from the first stage with stirring until the mixture being paste. After standing for a while, the paste was dissolved in enough amount of acetonitrile–water mixture (3:2 <ce:italic>v</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>v</ce:italic>). Finally, the solution was filtered and left to evaporate at room temperature. One or two days later, yellow crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained: yield based on α-H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>·<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O: about 80%. Elemental analysis, found (%) C, 14.09; H, 2.20; N, 3.49; calculated for [{Gd(NMP)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}(PMo<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (%); C, 13.98; H, 2.10; N, 3.26. Weight loss of 22.5% below 550 °C without obvious endothermic peak and with two exothermic peaks at 300 °C (where the Gd–O bonds break with the oxidation of NMP molecules) and 473 °C (where the heteropoly anionic cages decompose to the lower oxides of the metals like MoO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>). Calc. 23.26% for six NMP for the title compound.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: [{Gd(NMP)6}(PMo12O40)] n . The formation of heteropolyacid gadolinium salts was realized by neutralization of the acids. α-H3PMo12O40⋅nH2O (3.8 g, 2 mmol) and GdCl3 (2 mmol) were dissolved in 15 ml water, and the solution was heated at a 80 °C water bath until being dry. Then 2 ml NMP was added to dried solid (2 g) from the first stage with stirring until the mixture being paste. After standing for a while, the paste was dissolved in enough amount of acetonitrile-water mixture (3:2 v/v). Finally, the solution was filtered and left to evaporate at room temperature. One or two days later, yellow crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained: yield based on α-H3PMo12O40⋅nH2O: about 80%. Elemental analysis, found (%) C, 14.09; H, 2.20; N, 3.49; calculated for [{Gd(NMP)6}(PMo12O40)] n  (%); C, 13.98; H, 2.10; N, 3.26. Weight loss of 22.5% below 550 °C without obvious endothermic peak and with two exothermic peaks at 300 °C (where the Gd-O bonds break with the oxidation of NMP molecules) and 473 °C (where the heteropoly anionic cages decompose to the lower oxides of the metals like MoO3). Calc. 23.26% for six NMP for the title compound.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Physical measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">C, H and N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. IR spectra of samples were recorded in KBr pellets with a Nicolet 170 SXFT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000–500 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The UV spectra were observed in aqueous with a UV-250 spectrometer in the range of 190–400 nm. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed in air on a Perkin Elmer-7 instrument with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from room temperature to 600 °C. The ESR spectrum of powder of the title compound was recorded on a Bruker ER-200-D-SRC spectrometer at X-band at 110 K.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Physical measurements

C, H and N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. IR spectra of samples were recorded in KBr pellets with a Nicolet 170 SXFT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000-500 cm-1. The UV spectra were observed in aqueous with a UV-250 spectrometer in the range of 190-400 nm. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed in air on a Perkin Elmer-7 instrument with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from room temperature to 600 °C. The ESR spectrum of powder of the title compound was recorded on a Bruker ER-200-D-SRC spectrometer at X-band at 110 K.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystal structure analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The crystal structure of the title compound was determined from single crystal X-ray diffraction data. The intensity data were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV image plate area detector with Mo<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Kα (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at 293(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. The crystal parameters and details of the structure solution and refinement are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL1"></ce:float-anchor>. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined using full-matrix least-squares calculations with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. All hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed to allow riding on the parent atoms to which they are attached and refined with individual isotropic displacement parameters. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL-97 program . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL2"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL3"></ce:float-anchor>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure analysis

The crystal structure of the title compound was determined from single crystal X-ray diffraction data. The intensity data were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV image plate area detector with MoKα (λ=0.71073Å) at 293(2)K. The crystal parameters and details of the structure solution and refinement are listed in  . The structure was solved by direct methods and refined using full-matrix least-squares calculations with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. All hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed to allow riding on the parent atoms to which they are attached and refined with individual isotropic displacement parameters. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL-97 program . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in   , respectively.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Stable crystal of the title compound was obtained from acetonitrile–water mixture at room temperature. Experiments proved that selection of suitable solvent mixture was crucial for growing crystals of the title compounds. The title compound is soluble in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN and its mixtures with water. When it was dissolved in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN, irregular crystals were obtained because the solvent is lost too quickly. Therefore, it is necessary to control the evaporation rate of the solution. Adding some water to the acetonitrile solved this problem. Using this method, suitable crystals are eventually obtained. In addition, exposure of the crystallization solutions to sunlight should be avoided, since the crystals are sensitive to sunlight, the reasons for which have been discussed above.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Stable crystal of the title compound was obtained from acetonitrile-water mixture at room temperature. Experiments proved that selection of suitable solvent mixture was crucial for growing crystals of the title compounds. The title compound is soluble in CH3CN and its mixtures with water. When it was dissolved in CH3CN, irregular crystals were obtained because the solvent is lost too quickly. Therefore, it is necessary to control the evaporation rate of the solution. Adding some water to the acetonitrile solved this problem. Using this method, suitable crystals are eventually obtained. In addition, exposure of the crystallization solutions to sunlight should be avoided, since the crystals are sensitive to sunlight, the reasons for which have been discussed above.

The title compound consists of 1D infinite zigzag chains built from alternate polyanions and [Gd(NMP)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> units in the crystal ()<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>. The coordination environment of Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>. The coordination numbers of Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions are 8, six O atoms are from the NMP ligands, and the remaining two O atoms are from two adjacent heteropolyanions. The coordination polyhedra around the Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions can be described as a bicapped trigonal prism (), which is one of common coordination geometries for complexes with coordination number of 8 . In the title compounds, each Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion, has three NMP moleculars forming one trigonal plane upper, and three NMP moleculars forming the other trigonal plane bottom, and two terminal oxygen atoms of the polyanions occupying the caps due to the steric hindering of the polyanions; all these are benefit for the stability of the title compounds. In addition, O(11)#1–Gd(1)–O(7) bond angle is 123.69(16)°, resulting in the forming of zigzag chains. For Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions in the title compound, two trigonal planes are composed by O(41), O(45), O(46), and O(42), O(43), O(44), the distances between Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> and two trigonal planes are 1.5260 and 1.4505<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively; coplanar O(43), O(44), O(45), O(46) form one square face (the average plane deviation is 0.0737<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), with O(7) as a cap; and coplanar O(41), O(42), O(44), O(46) form one square face (the average plane deviation is 0.1360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), with O(11) as a cap. In addition, the Gd–O bond distances range from 2.282 to 2.554<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the average bond distance for all Gd–O bonds is 2.376<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is 0.058<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å shorter than the Gd(2)–O bond distance (2.434<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) of [Gd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(bbpen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)]ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·5CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH,  in which the Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> (2) ion has eight oxygen atoms in its coordination sphere which can be described as a distorted bicapped trigonal prism; and which is 0.024<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å longer than the Gd–O1A bond distance (2.352<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) of [Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(NITBzImH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·2THF·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (NITBzImH=nitronyl nitroxide radicals),  in which the coordination number of the Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion is eight and the coordination polyhedron around the Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion is a distorted cube. elements.clean_text: Molecular structure unit of the title compound is shown in  . The title compound consists of 1D infinite zigzag chains built from alternate polyanions and [Gd(NMP)6]3+ units in the crystal (). The coordination environment of Gd3+ is shown in  . The coordination numbers of Gd3+ ions are 8, six O atoms are from the NMP ligands, and the remaining two O atoms are from two adjacent heteropolyanions. The coordination polyhedra around the Gd3+ ions can be described as a bicapped trigonal prism (), which is one of common coordination geometries for complexes with coordination number of 8 . In the title compounds, each Gd3+ ion, has three NMP moleculars forming one trigonal plane upper, and three NMP moleculars forming the other trigonal plane bottom, and two terminal oxygen atoms of the polyanions occupying the caps due to the steric hindering of the polyanions; all these are benefit for the stability of the title compounds. In addition, O(11)#1-Gd(1)-O(7) bond angle is 123.69(16)°, resulting in the forming of zigzag chains. For Gd3+ ions in the title compound, two trigonal planes are composed by O(41), O(45), O(46), and O(42), O(43), O(44), the distances between Gd3+ and two trigonal planes are 1.5260 and 1.4505Å, respectively; coplanar O(43), O(44), O(45), O(46) form one square face (the average plane deviation is 0.0737Å), with O(7) as a cap; and coplanar O(41), O(42), O(44), O(46) form one square face (the average plane deviation is 0.1360Å), with O(11) as a cap. In addition, the Gd-O bond distances range from 2.282 to 2.554Å and the average bond distance for all Gd-O bonds is 2.376Å, which is 0.058Å shorter than the Gd(2)-O bond distance (2.434Å) of [Gd3(bbpen)2(CH3COO)4(CH3OH)]ClO4⋅5CH3OH,  in which the Gd3+ (2) ion has eight oxygen atoms in its coordination sphere which can be described as a distorted bicapped trigonal prism; and which is 0.024Å longer than the Gd-O1A bond distance (2.352Å) of [GdIII(NITBzImH)4](ClO4)3⋅2THF⋅2H2O (NITBzImH=nitronyl nitroxide radicals),  in which the coordination number of the Gd3+ ion is eight and the coordination polyhedron around the Gd3+ ion is a distorted cube. The fact of the mean Gd-O(NMP) bond distance, 2.330Å, is 0.184Å shorter than the average Gd-O t  bond distance, 2.514Å, indicates that the Gd-O(NMP) bonds are more stable than the Gd-O t  bonds, that is probably because the charge density over the oxygen of CO is bigger than that of O t , resulting from the electron-donating effect of the methyl groups through the N atoms in NMP moleculars and the electron-withdrawing effect of the polyanions.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In addition, the Mo–O<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>t</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–Gd–O<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>t</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>–Mo links are important: firstly because polyoxometalates as ligands are electron acceptors which, in some cases, can be reduced by one or more electrons, giving rise to mixed valence clusters. Secondly because rare-earth atoms with magnetic properties are introduced into the structures of the title compound, it should be possible to become novel solid-state materials in which delocalized electrons coexist with localized magnetic moments, thus, affording the opportunity for the investigation of molecular systems combining magnetic and conducting properties. We are currently investigating these properties.</ce:para>

elements.clean_text: There are four characteristic asymmetric vibrations resulting from heteropolyanions with Keggin structure, namely, ν as(Mo=O t ), ν as(Mo-O b ), ν as(Mo-O c ), and ν as(P-O a ). Comparing the IR spectra of the title compound with those of α-H3PMo12O40⋅nH2O  the vibration band of the MoO t  bond red-shifted from 975 to 961 cm-1 for the title compound; the peak duo to the Mo-O c  bonds red-shifted from 810 to 799 cm-1; the P-O a  bond vibrations are red-shifted from 1067 to 1063 cm-1; while the vibration band of Mo-O b  bonds blue-shifted from 870 to 881 cm-1. These results indicate that the polyanions in the title compound still retain the basic Keggin structure, but are distorted due to the effects of coordination. This is agreement with the results of the single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. In addition, there are three characteristic asymmetric vibrations resulting from NMP molecules, namely, ν as(CO), ν as(C-N) and ν as(N-CH3). Comparing the IR spectra of the title compounds with those of NMP molecules , the ν as(CO) decreases by 22.5 cm-1(from 1666.1 to 1644 cm-1) for the title compound. This result confirms that the NMP as ligands are coordinated to the rare-earth ions by means of their oxygen atoms. The ν as(C-N) and ν as(N-CH3) frequencies in the compound rise slightly by 8 and 6 cm-1, respectively. This can be explained by the fact that the charge density over the oxygen and carbon atoms is decreased due to the O atoms of the CO bonds being coordinated to rare-earth ions, leading to an increase in the electron-donating effect of the methyl groups through N atoms. The IR spectra studies show that there is strong interaction between the polyanions and organic groups in solid state.

elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The structure of one 1:1 composite compound prepared with polyoxometalate (POM)[PMo12O40]3- and the cations [Gd(NMP)6]3+ presents a type of zigzag chains with alternating cations and anions through Mo-O t -Gd-O t -Mo links in the crystal.

<ce:para view="all">Molecular structure unit of the title compound is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>. The title compound consists of 1D infinite zigzag chains built from alternate polyanions and [Gd(NMP)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> units in the crystal ()<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>. The coordination environment of Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>. The coordination numbers of Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions are 8, six O atoms are from the NMP ligands, and the remaining two O atoms are from two adjacent heteropolyanions. The coordination polyhedra around the Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions can be described as a bicapped trigonal prism (), which is one of common coordination geometries for complexes with coordination number of 8 . In the title compounds, each Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion, has three NMP moleculars forming one trigonal plane upper, and three NMP moleculars forming the other trigonal plane bottom, and two terminal oxygen atoms of the polyanions occupying the caps due to the steric hindering of the polyanions; all these are benefit for the stability of the title compounds. In addition, O(11)#1–Gd(1)–O(7) bond angle is 123.69(16)°, resulting in the forming of zigzag chains. For Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions in the title compound, two trigonal planes are composed by O(41), O(45), O(46), and O(42), O(43), O(44), the distances between Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> and two trigonal planes are 1.5260 and 1.4505<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively; coplanar O(43), O(44), O(45), O(46) form one square face (the average plane deviation is 0.0737<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), with O(7) as a cap; and coplanar O(41), O(42), O(44), O(46) form one square face (the average plane deviation is 0.1360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), with O(11) as a cap. In addition, the Gd–O bond distances range from 2.282 to 2.554<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the average bond distance for all Gd–O bonds is 2.376<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is 0.058<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å shorter than the Gd(2)–O bond distance (2.434<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) of [Gd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(bbpen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)]ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·5CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH,  in which the Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> (2) ion has eight oxygen atoms in its coordination sphere which can be described as a distorted bicapped trigonal prism; and which is 0.024<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å longer than the Gd–O1A bond distance (2.352<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) of [Gd<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(NITBzImH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·2THF·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (NITBzImH=nitronyl nitroxide radicals),  in which the coordination number of the Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion is eight and the coordination polyhedron around the Gd<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion is a distorted cube. The fact of the mean Gd–O(NMP) bond distance, 2.330<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, is 0.184<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å shorter than the average Gd–O<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>t</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> bond distance, 2.514<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, indicates that the Gd–O(NMP) bonds are more stable than the Gd–O<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>t</ce:italic>

</ce:inf> bonds red-shifted from 810 to 799 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>; the P–O<ce:inf loc="post">

</ce:inf> bond vibrations are red-shifted from 1067 to 1063 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>; while the vibration band of Mo–O<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> bonds blue-shifted from 870 to 881 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. These results indicate that the polyanions in the title compound still retain the basic Keggin structure, but are distorted due to the effects of coordination. This is agreement with the results of the single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. In addition, there are three characteristic asymmetric vibrations resulting from NMP molecules, namely, <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf>(CO), <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>

This result confirms that the NMP as ligands are coordinated to the rare-earth ions by means of their oxygen atoms. The <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>

cln_elements.clean_text:
Molecular structure unit of the title compound is shown in  . The title compound consists of 1D infinite zigzag chains built from alternate polyanions and [Gd(NMP)6]3+ units in the crystal (). The coordination environment of Gd3+ is shown in  . The coordination numbers of Gd3+ ions are 8, six O atoms are from the NMP ligands, and the remaining two O atoms are from two adjacent heteropolyanions. The coordination polyhedra around the Gd3+ ions can be described as a bicapped trigonal prism (), which is one of common coordination geometries for complexes with coordination number of 8 . In the title compounds, each Gd3+ ion, has three NMP moleculars forming one trigonal plane upper, and three NMP moleculars forming the other trigonal plane bottom, and two terminal oxygen atoms of the polyanions occupying the caps due to the steric hindering of the polyanions; all these are benefit for the stability of the title compounds. In addition, O(11)#1-Gd(1)-O(7) bond angle is 123.69(16)°, resulting in the forming of zigzag chains. For Gd3+ ions in the title compound, two trigonal planes are composed by O(41), O(45), O(46), and O(42), O(43), O(44), the distances between Gd3+ and two trigonal planes are 1.5260 and 1.4505Å, respectively; coplanar O(43), O(44), O(45), O(46) form one square face (the average plane deviation is 0.0737Å), with O(7) as a cap; and coplanar O(41), O(42), O(44), O(46) form one square face (the average plane deviation is 0.1360Å), with O(11) as a cap. In addition, the Gd-O bond distances range from 2.282 to 2.554Å and the average bond distance for all Gd-O bonds is 2.376Å, which is 0.058Å shorter than the Gd(2)-O bond distance (2.434Å) of [Gd3(bbpen)2(CH3COO)4(CH3OH)]ClO4⋅5CH3OH,  in which the Gd3+ (2) ion has eight oxygen atoms in its coordination sphere which can be described as a distorted bicapped trigonal prism; and which is 0.024Å longer than the Gd-O1A bond distance (2.352Å) of [GdIII(NITBzImH)4](ClO4)3⋅2THF⋅2H2O (NITBzImH=nitronyl nitroxide radicals),  in which the coordination number of the Gd3+ ion is eight and the coordination polyhedron around the Gd3+ ion is a distorted cube. The fact of the mean Gd-O(NMP) bond distance, 2.330Å, is 0.184Å shorter than the average Gd-O t  bond distance, 2.514Å, indicates that the Gd-O(NMP) bonds are more stable than the Gd-O t  bonds, that is probably because the charge density over the oxygen of CO is bigger than that of O t , resulting from the electron-donating effect of the methyl groups through the N atoms in NMP moleculars and the electron-withdrawing effect of the polyanions.

The P-O bond distances range from 1.524 to 1.551Å for the title compound, and the O-P-O bond angles range from 109.1 to 110.1°. These results show that the PO4 tetrahedrons are distorted to small extent. The Mo-O t  bond distances range from 1.669 to 1.695Å, mean 1.682Å; the Mo-O a  19 bond distances range from 2.388 to 2.463Å, mean 2.424Å; the Mo-O b,c  19 bond distances range from 1.809 to 2.033Å. These results show that the MoO6 octahedra of the polyanions in the title compounds are severely distorted because of the influence of the outer coordination cations.

There are four characteristic asymmetric vibrations resulting from heteropolyanions with Keggin structure, namely, ν as(Mo=O t ), ν as(Mo-O b ), ν as(Mo-O c ), and ν as(P-O a ). Comparing the IR spectra of the title compound with those of α-H3PMo12O40⋅nH2O  the vibration band of the MoO t  bond red-shifted from 975 to 961 cm-1 for the title compound; the peak duo to the Mo-O c  bonds red-shifted from 810 to 799 cm-1; the P-O a  bond vibrations are red-shifted from 1067 to 1063 cm-1; while the vibration band of Mo-O b  bonds blue-shifted from 870 to 881 cm-1. These results indicate that the polyanions in the title compound still retain the basic Keggin structure, but are distorted due to the effects of coordination. This is agreement with the results of the single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. In addition, there are three characteristic asymmetric vibrations resulting from NMP molecules, namely, ν as(CO), ν as(C-N) and ν as(N-CH3). Comparing the IR spectra of the title compounds with those of NMP molecules , the ν as(CO) decreases by 22.5 cm-1(from 1666.1 to 1644 cm-1) for the title compound. This result confirms that the NMP as ligands are coordinated to the rare-earth ions by means of their oxygen atoms. The ν as(C-N) and ν as(N-CH3) frequencies in the compound rise slightly by 8 and 6 cm-1, respectively. This can be explained by the fact that the charge density over the oxygen and carbon atoms is decreased due to the O atoms of the CO bonds being coordinated to rare-earth ions, leading to an increase in the electron-donating effect of the methyl groups through N atoms. The IR spectra studies show that there is strong interaction between the polyanions and organic groups in solid state.

ESR spectroscopy of Gd3+ ion, with a 4f7 electronic configuration (8S7/2), can be observed at room temperature . Since the spin-lattice relaxation time is shortened due to strong spin-orbit coupling in Gd3+ ions at low temperature, The ESR spectroscopy of Gd3+ ion in the title compound is more obvious at 110 K than at room temperature, as shown in  , there are three groups of lines with effective g-values of approximate 5.74, 2.46 and 2.00, and wide absorption band for magnetic fields corresponding to g<2.
